source.name: City of Jacksonville Public Works - Solid Waste
source.notes: Based on official City of Jacksonville recycling service standards. Uses yellow-lid recycling cart. Plastics #1-3, #5, #7 only. Lids must be removed from bottles.

materials.name: Plastic water and soda bottles (#1 PET)
instructions: Empty and rinse the bottle
Remove the lid and discard it in trash
Place bottle loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: #1 PET/PETE plastic is the most commonly recycled plastic
Jacksonville requires lids be removed from all bottles
commonMistakes: Don't leave the lid on — Jacksonville requires lids removed
Don't crush bottles; leave them intact for sorting
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic detergent and cleaning bottles (#2 HDPE)
instructions: Empty and rinse thoroughly
Remove the lid and discard in trash
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: #2 HDPE plastic — commonly found in detergent, shampoo, and milk jugs
One of the most valuable recycled plastics
commonMistakes: Don't leave lids on
Don't include bottles with significant residue
Don't bag recyclables

materials.name: Plastic containers (#3 PVC/V)
instructions: Empty and clean the container
Remove any lids
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: #3 PVC is accepted in Jacksonville but is less common in consumer packaging
Look for the #3 recycling symbol on the bottom
commonMistakes: Don't confuse PVC pipes (construction waste) with PVC containers
Don't include flexible PVC film or wraps
examples: Rigid clear food packaging with #3 symbol

materials.name: Plastic containers (#5 PP)
instructions: Empty and rinse the container
Remove any lids
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: #5 PP is accepted in Jacksonville — commonly found in food tubs and deli containers
Microwave-safe containers are often #5 PP
commonMistakes: Don't include containers still containing food residue
Don't include lids — they go in the trash in Jacksonville

materials.name: Plastic containers (#7 Other)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove lids
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: #7 is a catch-all for other plastics; Jacksonville accepts it
Less commonly recycled elsewhere, but accepted here
commonMistakes: Don't assume all #7 plastics are biodegradable (PLA is also #7)
Don't include heavily contaminated items

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle lids separately with metal cans)
Place glass loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Jacksonville accepts green, brown, and clear glass
Labels can stay on — they burn off during processing
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in trash for safety
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics
Don't include drinking glasses or Pyrex — they have different melting points

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Leave the tab on
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable and highly valuable
A recycled can is back on shelves in as little as 60 days
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans — Jacksonville sorting equipment works better with intact cans
Don't include aluminum foil or foil pans (these go in trash in Jacksonville)

materials.name: Steel and tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse the can
Labels can stay on
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Use a magnet to check — steel and tin are magnetic, aluminum is not
Accepted in Jacksonville recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Don't include aerosol cans — check specific instructions

materials.name: Newspapers and inserts
instructions: Keep dry
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
Inserts and ads can stay inside the newspaper
notes: Newspaper is one of the most successfully recycled materials
Glossy inserts are accepted along with the paper
commonMistakes: Don't recycle wet or moldy newspaper — it goes in trash
Don't bag newspapers in plastic bags

materials.name: Magazines, catalogs, and phone books
instructions: Keep dry
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
No need to remove staples or subscription cards
notes: Glossy paper is accepted in Jacksonville recycling
Phone books are specifically listed as accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags
Don't include wet or soiled magazines

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, styrofoam, air pillows)
Keep dry
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart or beside it if too large
notes: Corrugated cardboard is highly recyclable
Flatten to save space in the cart
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food
Don't leave packing materials inside
Don't include wax-coated cardboard

materials.name: Paper, mail, and envelopes
instructions: Keep dry
Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag before recycling
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Envelopes with plastic windows are accepted
Staples and paper clips are OK — they're removed during processing
commonMistakes: Don't include wet or soiled paper
Don't include paper towels, napkins, or tissues
Don't include wax-coated or laminated paper

materials.name: Cereal and paper boxes (paperboard)
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove any plastic liners or bags inside
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Thin paperboard/chipboard is recyclable in Jacksonville
Remove the plastic liner bag (it goes in the trash)
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag
Don't include boxes soiled with food

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in yellow-lid recycling cart
Can be used to contain shredded paper for recycling
notes: Paper bags are recyclable and also useful for containing loose paper recyclables
commonMistakes: Don't include paper bags contaminated with grease or food

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do not puncture or crush
Remove plastic cap and discard in trash
Place can loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans are accepted
The can itself is recyclable metal
commonMistakes: Don't recycle aerosol cans that still have contents — they're hazardous
Don't puncture cans

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place loose in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Both refrigerated (gable-top) and shelf-stable (aseptic) cartons are accepted
These are made from layers of paper, plastic, and sometimes aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons — the 3D shape helps sorting machines identify them
Don't include juice pouches (like Capri Sun) — those go in trash

materials.name: Aluminum foil and foil pans
instructions: Place in trash cart
Foil is often too contaminated with food to recycle in Jacksonville
notes: While aluminum foil is technically recyclable, Jacksonville does not accept it in curbside recycling due to food contamination
commonMistakes: Don't put foil or foil pans in the recycling cart

materials.name: Plastic bags, wraps, and film
instructions: Place in trash cart
Many grocery stores accept clean plastic bags for recycling (Publix, Walmart)
Never place plastic bags in the recycling cart
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in Jacksonville's recycling stream
They tangle in sorting machinery and shut down the recycling facility
commonMistakes: NEVER bag recyclables in plastic bags — put items loose in the cart
Don't put any plastic film, wrap, or bags in the yellow-lid cart

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene foam
instructions: Place in trash cart
Break into smaller pieces if needed to fit
Not recyclable in Jacksonville
notes: Expanded polystyrene foam is not accepted in Jacksonville recycling
This includes food containers, cups, plates, and packing materials
commonMistakes: Don't put any styrofoam in the recycling cart
Don't confuse rigid plastic containers with foam

materials.name: Diapers and hygiene products
instructions: Roll up and secure with tabs
Place in trash cart
Double-bag if needed to contain odor
notes: Diapers contain mixed materials and human waste — they are never recyclable
Specifically listed as not accepted in Jacksonville recycling
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the recycling cart

materials.name: Soiled or wet paper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Paper contaminated with food, grease, or liquids cannot be recycled
notes: Grease and food residue ruin paper fibers during the recycling process
Even a small amount of grease can contaminate an entire batch
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy pizza boxes — tear off the clean top and recycle that
Don't recycle paper plates or napkins used with food

materials.name: Candy wrappers, chip bags, and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash cart
These are made from mixed materials that cannot be separated for recycling
notes: Despite their metallic appearance, these are not aluminum
They are made from layers of plastic and metal film bonded together
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the metallic look is deceiving
Don't mistake chip bags for recyclable aluminum

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: If wearable, donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local thrift stores
If not wearable, place in trash cart
Never place in recycling cart
notes: Jacksonville does not accept textiles in curbside recycling
Consider donating wearable items to extend their life
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the recycling cart
Don't assume torn items can't be donated — textile recyclers accept them

materials.name: Tools and hardware
instructions: Place small tools and hardware in trash cart
Large power tools: schedule a bulk pickup with Jacksonville Public Works
Call (904) 630-CITY (2489) for bulk pickup
notes: Tools are specifically listed as not accepted in Jacksonville recycling
Metal tools can sometimes be donated or taken to scrap metal recyclers
commonMistakes: Don't put tools in the recycling cart
Don't put power tools with batteries in the trash — remove battery first

materials.name: Toys
instructions: If in good condition, donate to Goodwill or Toys for Tots
If broken, place in trash cart
Remove batteries before disposing
notes: Toys are specifically listed as not accepted in Jacksonville recycling
They are made of mixed materials that cannot be sorted
commonMistakes: Don't put toys in the recycling cart
Don't forget to remove batteries from electronic toys

materials.name: Construction and demolition waste
instructions: Not accepted in curbside carts
Small amounts: schedule a bulk pickup at (904) 630-CITY (2489)
Large amounts: hire a private hauler or take to Trail Ridge Landfill
notes: Construction waste is specifically prohibited from Jacksonville recycling
C&D waste requires special disposal
commonMistakes: Don't place in recycling or regular trash carts
Don't put in yard waste

materials.name: Plastic utensils and straws
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small and lightweight to be captured by recycling sorting equipment
notes: Even though made of recyclable plastic types, utensils and straws are too small for sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — they fall through sorting screens
Consider switching to reusable utensils

materials.name: Bubble wrap and air pillows
instructions: Deflate air pillows
Place in trash cart
Some grocery stores accept clean bubble wrap with plastic bag recycling
notes: Bubble wrap is plastic film and is not accepted in Jacksonville curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling cart — it's a type of plastic film

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash cart
The wax coating prevents paper recycling
notes: Wax-coated paper cannot be recycled because the wax contaminates the paper pulp
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the wax coating is not removable during processing

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in trash cart
The plastic lining inside makes them non-recyclable
Plastic lid goes in trash too
notes: Paper coffee cups have a thin polyethylene lining that prevents recycling
The cardboard sleeve can be recycled separately
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the plastic lining contaminates paper recycling
The cardboard sleeve IS recyclable — separate it

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in trash cart
Thermal paper contains BPA and is not recyclable
notes: Most receipts use thermal paper which contains BPA/BPS chemicals
These chemicals contaminate recycled paper products
commonMistakes: Don't recycle receipts — they contaminate paper recycling
If receipt is clearly not thermal (laser-printed), it can be recycled

materials.name: Mirrors, window glass, and ceramics
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard for safety
Place in trash cart
Label 'broken glass' if sharp
notes: Window glass, mirrors, and ceramics have different chemical compositions than bottle glass
They melt at different temperatures and contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — only bottle and jar glass is recyclable
Don't confuse drinking glasses with glass bottles

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Wire hangers can be returned to dry cleaners for reuse
Donate good hangers to thrift stores
notes: Hangers tangle in recycling machinery regardless of material
commonMistakes: Don't put any type of hanger in the recycling cart

materials.name: Pens, markers, and tape
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small and made of mixed materials to recycle
notes: These items are made of multiple bonded materials that can't be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Crayola and Terracycle offer mail-back programs for markers

materials.name: Fast food wrappers and containers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Grease and food residue make these non-recyclable
notes: Most fast food packaging is contaminated with food and grease
Even if the paper looks clean, the lining is often non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy food packaging

materials.name: Plastic lids and bottle caps
instructions: Remove from bottles and place in trash cart
Jacksonville specifically requires lids removed from recyclable bottles
notes: Lids are too small for sorting equipment and are often a different plastic type than the bottle
This is a Jacksonville-specific rule — some cities allow caps on
commonMistakes: Don't leave lids on bottles in Jacksonville recycling
Don't toss loose lids in recycling — they fall through screens

materials.name: Paper towels, napkins, and tissues
instructions: Place in trash cart
Paper fibers are too short and contaminated to recycle
notes: Used paper towels and napkins have absorbed moisture and often food/grease
Even unused ones have fibers too short for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't recycle used paper towels or tissues
Don't compost if contaminated with cleaning chemicals

materials.name: Rubber items
instructions: Place in trash cart
Rubber is not recyclable in Jacksonville's curbside program
notes: Rubber tangles in recycling machinery similar to plastic bags
commonMistakes: Don't put rubber items in recycling
Garden hoses are especially problematic — they wrap around machinery

materials.name: Medical waste
instructions: Place in trash cart (non-sharp items)
Sharps (needles, lancets) must be placed in approved sharps container
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Medical waste is specifically prohibited from Jacksonville recycling
For sharps disposal, see the sharps/needles entry
commonMistakes: Never put medical waste in recycling
Never put loose sharps in any curbside cart

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: If heavily soiled with grease: place in trash
If the top half is clean: tear it off and recycle the clean portion
Greasy bottom always goes in trash
notes: Grease saturates cardboard fibers making them non-recyclable
The clean lid can often be separated and recycled
commonMistakes: Don't recycle the greasy parts — tear off and recycle only the clean portions

materials.name: Juice pouches and drink pouches
instructions: Place in trash cart
Made of layers of plastic and metal that cannot be separated
notes: Pouches are made of flexible multi-layer packaging that is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle pouches — they are not the same as cartons

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Jacksonville provides separate yard waste collection
Place in designated yard waste containers or bags
Branches must be cut to 4 feet or less and bundled
Do NOT place in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Yard waste is specifically prohibited from the recycling cart
Jacksonville has regular yard waste pickup — check your schedule
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in the recycling cart
Don't use plastic bags for yard waste — use paper bags or containers

materials.name: Food scraps (general)
instructions: Place in trash cart
Bag food waste to contain odor and prevent pests
Jacksonville does not have a curbside composting program
notes: Food scraps are not accepted in Jacksonville recycling
Consider home composting to reduce landfill waste
commonMistakes: Never put food waste in the recycling cart

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in trash cart
Ideal for home composting if you have a compost bin
Not accepted in recycling
notes: Jacksonville does not offer curbside composting
Fruit and vegetable scraps are excellent for backyard composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place in trash cart
Great for home composting if you have a bin
K-cups: trash (some brands offer recyclable pods)
notes: No curbside composting in Jacksonville, but coffee grounds are excellent for garden compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Check if your K-cup brand is recyclable — most are not

materials.name: Eggshells
instructions: Place in trash cart
Excellent for home composting — crush before adding to compost bin
notes: No curbside composting in Jacksonville
Eggshells add calcium to garden soil
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or recycling carts
Take to a household hazardous waste collection event
Many retailers accept batteries: Home Depot, Lowe's, Best Buy
Car batteries: return to auto parts store
notes: Batteries are specifically listed as not accepted in Jacksonville recycling
Lithium batteries are a fire hazard in trash and recycling trucks
commonMistakes: NEVER put lithium batteries in trash — they cause fires
Don't put any batteries in the recycling cart

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Latex paint: dry out small amounts with kitty litter, then trash the solid
Oil-based paint: take to household hazardous waste event
Never pour paint down drains
Check Jacksonville's HHW collection schedule
notes: Oil-based paint is hazardous waste
Dried latex paint in small quantities can go in regular trash
commonMistakes: Never pour paint down the drain or onto the ground
Don't put liquid paint cans in the trash

materials.name: Motor oil and antifreeze
instructions: Never pour down drains or on the ground
Many auto parts stores accept used motor oil (AutoZone, O'Reilly)
Take to household hazardous waste collection
notes: One gallon of used oil can contaminate one million gallons of water
Used motor oil is re-refined into new oil
commonMistakes: Never pour down storm drains — Jacksonville waterways flow to the St. Johns River
Don't mix motor oil with other fluids

materials.name: Pesticides, herbicides, and household chemicals
instructions: Never pour down drains or into storm drains
Take to Jacksonville household hazardous waste collection
Keep in original containers with labels intact
notes: Pesticides and chemicals are serious environmental hazards
Jacksonville periodically holds HHW collection events — check jacksonville.gov
commonMistakes: Never pour chemicals down the drain
Don't mix different chemicals together

materials.name: Propane tanks and compressed gas
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Small camping cylinders: take to HHW collection
Large grill tanks: exchange at hardware stores or take to propane dealer
notes: Pressurized containers can explode in compactor trucks
Many home improvement stores offer tank exchange programs
commonMistakes: NEVER place in trash or recycling — explosion risk
Don't puncture or attempt to empty tanks yourself

materials.name: Fluorescent bulbs and CFLs
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Take to Home Depot or Lowe's for free recycling
Or bring to Jacksonville HHW collection event
notes: Fluorescent bulbs contain mercury and must be handled carefully
If broken, ventilate the area and follow EPA cleanup guidelines
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — mercury is hazardous
Don't break bulbs — mercury vapor is released

materials.name: Medications and pharmaceuticals
instructions: Take to a DEA-authorized pharmacy drop-off location
Jacksonville Sheriff's Office has medication take-back boxes
Do not flush medications down the toilet
Do not put in trash or recycling
notes: Flushing medications contaminates water supplies
Jacksonville has several permanent medication drop-off sites
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in regular trash where they could be accessed by others

materials.name: Electronics / e-waste (small)
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling carts
Take to an e-waste recycling facility
Best Buy accepts most small electronics for free
Call (904) 630-CITY for e-waste collection information
notes: Electronics are specifically prohibited from Jacksonville recycling
E-waste contains both hazardous materials and valuable recoverable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in the recycling cart
Remove batteries before dropping off

materials.name: Televisions and monitors
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling carts
Best Buy accepts TVs up to 32 inches for free
Larger TVs: contact a certified e-waste recycler
Call (904) 630-CITY for disposal options
notes: CRT TVs and monitors contain lead
LCD screens contain mercury backlights
commonMistakes: Don't leave TVs at the curb without scheduling pickup
Don't break screens — they may contain hazardous materials

materials.name: Computers and laptops
instructions: Wipe personal data before recycling
Best Buy and Staples accept computers for recycling
Some nonprofits accept working computers (Goodwill, etc.)
Call (904) 630-CITY for e-waste disposal options
notes: Erase hard drives or remove them before recycling for privacy
Working computers can be donated for reuse
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside carts
Don't forget to wipe personal data before recycling or donating

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Not accepted in curbside carts
Take to a tire retailer — most accept old tires when you buy new ones
Jacksonville occasionally holds tire amnesty collection events
notes: Tires are banned from Florida landfills
Illegally dumped tires collect rainwater and breed mosquitoes
commonMistakes: Don't leave tires at the curb
Don't illegally dump tires — it's a code violation in Jacksonville

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup with Jacksonville Public Works: (904) 630-CITY (2489)
Some appliance retailers offer haul-away when delivering new units
Scrap metal recyclers may accept large appliances
notes: Appliances with refrigerants (fridges, AC units) require special handling
Jacksonville offers scheduled bulk pickup for residents
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling pickup
Don't try to remove refrigerant yourself — it requires certification

materials.name: Mattresses and large furniture
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup with Jacksonville Public Works: (904) 630-CITY (2489)
If in good condition, donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or Habitat ReStore
Not accepted in regular curbside carts
notes: Jacksonville provides bulk pickup for large items — call to schedule
Usable furniture has great donation value
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling a bulk pickup
Don't put in yard waste area

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: absorb with paper towels and place in trash
Large amounts: store in sealed container and take to a recycling center
Never pour down drains — it causes sewer blockages
notes: Cooking oil can be recycled into biodiesel
Pouring grease down drains is the leading cause of sewer backups
commonMistakes: NEVER pour cooking oil or grease down the drain
Don't put liquid oil in the recycling cart

materials.name: Sharps and needles
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container or heavy-duty plastic container
When full, seal the container and take to an approved drop-off site
Jacksonville Fire and Rescue stations accept sealed sharps containers
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Loose needles endanger sanitation workers
Use a thick plastic laundry detergent bottle if you don't have a sharps container
commonMistakes: NEVER put loose needles in trash or recycling
Don't overfill sharps containers — seal when 3/4 full

materials.name: Incandescent and LED light bulbs
instructions: Wrap in paper or place in original packaging
Place in trash cart
Incandescent and LED bulbs do not contain mercury
notes: Unlike CFLs, incandescent and LED bulbs are not hazardous
They are not recyclable through curbside programs due to their mixed materials
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs — CFLs contain mercury and need special handling
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper inside a paper bag
Staple or fold the bag closed
Place the bag in yellow-lid recycling cart
notes: Loose shredded paper blows away and jams machinery
Containing it in a paper bag keeps it together through processing
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the cart — it must be bagged in a paper bag
Don't use a plastic bag to contain shredded paper

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate books in good condition to Jacksonville Public Library or thrift stores
Damaged books: remove hardcovers and recycle the paper pages
Hardcovers go in trash
notes: Paper pages are recyclable; hardcovers have mixed materials (glue, fabric, cardboard)
Donation is always preferred over recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw away books that could be donated
Hardcovers should be removed before recycling the pages

recycle: Plastics #1, #2, #3, #5, #7 — bottles and containers only, lids removed
Glass bottles and jars (green, brown, clear)
Newspapers, inserts, magazines, catalogs, phone books
Cereal boxes and paperboard (flatten, remove liners)
compost: Yard waste (separate collection — grass, leaves, branches)
trash: Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags — they jam sorting machinery
Styrofoam cups, plates, containers, packing peanuts
Mirrors, window glass, ceramics, drinking glasses
Plastic lids and bottle caps (remove from bottles)

tips: Empty. Clean. Dry. — the three rules for Jacksonville recycling
All recyclables must be placed LOOSE in the yellow-lid cart — never bagged
Remove lids from all bottles before recycling (Jacksonville-specific rule)
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space in your cart
When in doubt, throw it out — contamination hurts the entire recycling stream
Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant — bring them to Publix or Walmart instead
Rinse food containers — they don't need to be spotless, just reasonably clean
Greasy pizza box? Tear off the clean top to recycle, trash the greasy bottom
Schedule bulk pickups for large items: (904) 630-CITY (2489)
Check jacksonville.gov for household hazardous waste collection events

locations.name: Jacksonville Household Hazardous Waste Collection
locations.notes: Periodic collection events — check jacksonville.gov for schedule

locations.name: Jacksonville Public Works - Solid Waste Division
locations.notes: Call (904) 630-CITY (2489) for all solid waste services
